citation.article-title: Microbacterium agarici sp. nov., Microbacterium humi sp. nov. and Microbacterium pseudoresistens sp. nov., isolated from the base of the mushroom Agaricus blazei
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Microbacterium pseudoresistens sp. nov.

Microbacterium pseudoresistens (pseu.do.re.sis′tens. Gr. adj. pseudes false; L. part adj. resistens resisting and also a bacterial specific epithet; N.L. part. adj. pseudoresistens the false Microbacterium resistens).
Cells are short rods, about 2–3 μm in length and 1–1.2 μm in width.
Cells are Gram-positive, oxidase-positive and catalase-positive, showing aerobic respiratory metabolism.
Good growth occurs after 3 days incubation on R2A agar and NA at 25–30 °C; colonies on NA are yellow.
The peptidoglycan is of type B2α with an interpeptide bridge d-Glu→d-Orn.
The quinone system is composed of the predominant menaquinone MK-13 with minor amounts of MK-12 and MK-14.
The polar lipid profile consists of diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylglycerol and an unknown glycolipid and trace amounts of three unknown lipids.
The predominant polyamines are spermidine and spermine.
Major fatty acids are anteiso-C15 : 0, iso-C16 : 0 and anteiso-C17 : 0.
Differential physiological characteristics are given in Table 1.
Many sugar and other compounds utilized by M. resistens CCUG 38312T are not utilized, including d-galactose, l-rhamnose and acetate.
The type strain, CC-5209T (=DSM 22185T=CCM 7688T), was isolated from the stalk of the edible mushroom Agaricus blazei grown in the laboratory.
